title: 109_hr1738
content: The Act may be cited as the "End Institutionalized Abuse Against Children Act of 2005". The Justice Department will conduct investigations. The Attorney General will investigate foreign-based institutions to ensure the safety of American children, including compliance with local laws and regulations. Cooperation with foreign authorities is required to address any threats to children's safety. Rules will be established to protect American children in foreign institutions for behavior modification purposes. The Attorney General will investigate foreign-based institutions to ensure the safety of American children in care or treatment facilities for behavior modification. Violators of rules set under this subsection may face a civil penalty of up to $50,000. The Attorney General will investigate foreign-based institutions to ensure the safety of American children in care or treatment facilities for behavior modification. American children are defined as citizens or nationals 18 years of age or younger. AMENDMENTS TO DEPARTMENT OF STATE'S COUNTRY REPORTS ON HUMAN RIGHTS PRACTICES. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include a new subsection requiring a report on child abuse and human rights violations at institutions owned or operated by U.S. citizens or private entities in foreign countries. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to require a report on child abuse and human rights violations at institutions owned or operated by U.S. citizens or private entities in foreign countries, specifically focusing on those under 18 years of age. Title III of the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act authorizes grants to states for inspecting child residential treatment facilities. States must submit an application to the Secretary to be eligible for these grants. The Secretary may only grant funds to a State for child residential treatment facilities if the State has laws requiring licensing and is enforcing them. Licensing requirements include operators needing a license, meeting state standards for treatment services, and ensuring resident children's well-being. The facility must meet the standards of the child's home state, including licensing requirements. State laws on child abuse and neglect apply to the facility, with equivalent care standards enforced through unannounced inspections. Enforcement requirements for child residential treatment facilities include a civil penalty of $250 per day for violations of licensing standards, with a maximum penalty period of 60 days. Additionally, the state can order the termination of operations after a 60-day penalty period for non-compliance. The State can order the termination of operations for a child residential treatment facility involved in abuse or neglect, with civil penalties starting at $20,000 per violation. Any individual involved in the abuse or neglect of a child residing in a treatment facility can face fines or imprisonment for up to five years. Abuse or neglect is defined as a knowing act or omission that results in harm or presents a risk of serious harm to the child. The grant recipients must use funds to hire and train individuals for inspections of child residential treatment facilities and collect data for reports. Additionally, the funds should only supplement non-Federal funds, not replace them. The Secretary requires States receiving grants to submit detailed reports on child residential treatment facilities, including information on the number of facilities, children residing in them, their demographics, and disabilities. The term 'child' refers to an individual 18 years or younger. A 'child residential treatment facility' provides 24-hour care for unrelated children, offering specialized services for emotional, psychological, or behavioral issues. The term 'Secretary' refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The term 'State' includes all States, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. Authorization of appropriations for the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act is set at $50,000,000 for each of the fiscal years 2006 and 2007. This funding is designated for grants to states to support inspections of child residential treatment facilities.
